questions.text: The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in __
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of cochlea.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway is a prerequisite for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a painless swelling near the angle of his jaw,nasal obstruction,decreased hearing ability and occasional epistaxis. On performing hearing tests, conductive hearing loss is seen on the same side as the swelling. Examination of the swelling revealed a single enlarged lymph node, 5 cm in size and systemic examination revealed squint. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with cranial nerve involvement (indicating stage IV). The treatment of choice in this condition is radiotherapy + chemotherapy.

The given scenario describes nasal (obstruction and epistaxis), otologic (conductive hearing loss) and ophthalmic symptoms (squint) with cervical lymphadenopathy. This set of symptoms in an elderly man is highly suggestive of a tumor in the nasopharynx, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually originates from the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rossenmuller. It presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction due to blockage of the choana or the nasal cavity, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- Obstruction of the eustachian tube leads to unilateral conductive hearing loss, serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmologic- These symptoms occur due to the involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI.
    • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V.
    • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
  • Cervical node metastasis- Usually between the angle of jaw and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis- to bone, liver, lung, etc.

The treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Radiotherapy for stages I and II.
  • Radiotherapy + chemotherapy for stages III and IV.
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

TNM staging of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is given below:

  • T1 Tumour confined to the nasopharynx 
  • T2 Tumour extends to soft tissues of oropharynx and/or nasal fossa
    • T2a without parapharyngeal extension
    • T2b with parapharyngeal extension
  • T3 Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses 
  • T4 Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx or orbit or masticator space 

     Regional lymph nodes:

  • NX Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0 No regional lymph node metastasis 
  • N1 Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa
  • N2 Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, 6 cm or less in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa.
  • N3 Metastasis in a lymph node(s)
    • N3a Greater than 6 cm in dimension
    • N3b In the supraclavicular fossa

     Metastasis:

  • MX Distant metastasis cannot be assessed
  • M0 No distant metastasis
  • M1 Distant metastasis

     Stage grouping:

Stage T N M
0  Tis  N0  M0
I  T1 N0  M0
IIA  T2a  N0  M0
IIB   T1  N1 M0
  T2 N1 M0
  T2a N1 M0
  T2b N0, N1 M0
III T1 N2 M0
  T2a, T2b N2 M0
  T3 N0, N1, N2 M0
IVA T4 N0, N1, N2 M0
IVB Any T N3  
IVC Any T Any N M1

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in which of the following lesions:
questions.solution:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.

Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, ligate bleeding vessel and packing

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management will be to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, ligate the bleeding vessel, and do hemostatic packing.

Primary, reactionary and secondary hemorrhages are complications of tonsillectomy.

Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.

Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. On physical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted on ocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the best immediate step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma

Etiology:

  • Emboli - emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are - cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features are:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Amaurosis fugax - transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia. As seen in this patient.
  • Direct pupillary reflex is absent
  • Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive

Fundus examination shows:

  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance
  • Cherry red spot
  • Severe edema 
  • Retinal pallor

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis. In this type of conjunctivitis, there is inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Causes: 

  • Moraxella axenfeld
  • Moraxella lacunata
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause) 

The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. It spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye by contaminated hands and handkerchiefs. Oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days is the preferred treatment.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis.

Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis

Hyperacute  Acute Chronic
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus
Neisseria meningitidis Streptococcus pneumoniae Moraxella lacunata
  Haemophilus influenzae Enteric bacteria

 

Treatment:

  • Oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days
  • Zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic ferment.

questions.text: The CT image given below is of a patient with a history of trauma.What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

Orbital blow out fracture:

Isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blow-out fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum.

Clinical signs: Periocular swelling (early stage), Enophthalmos, ecchymosis, and subconjunctival hemorrhage (later stages).

Investigation: Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.

CT scan is used for the confirmation of the diagnosis.

Treatment: The initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.

Indications of surgery:

  • Enophthalmos
  • Diplopia
  • Ocular motility disorder
  • Immediate repair is indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present
  • Delayed repair is done with 2 weeks

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with chronic lower back pain and X-ray findings as below comes to the ophthalmology clinic with associated complaints of pain and redness in his left eye. Examination reveals a constricted pupil. Slit-lamp examination shows aqueous flare, keratic precipitates, and iris nodules. What is the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of ankylosing spondylitis, redness and pain in the eye, constricted pupil and aqueous flare has acute anterior uveitis. The X-ray shows the classical findings of 'bamboo spine' seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

The earliest sign of anterior uveitis is an aqueous flare.

Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

Corneal signs

Anterior chamber signs

Corneal edema

Aqueous cells

Keratic Precipitates

(Pathognomonic)

Aqueous flare (earliest sign)

Posterior corneal opacity

Hypopyon
 

Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae

 

Iris signs

Pupillary signs

Loss of normal pattern

 

Constricted pupil

Change in color

Irregular pupil shape

Iris nodules

  • Koeppe
  • Busacca

Ectropion of pupillary margin

Posterior synechiae

Occlusion pupillae

Neovascularization

  

Anterior uveitis is seen in association with the following conditions:

  • sarcoidosis,
  • ankylosing spondylitis,
  • juvenile rheumatoid arthritis,
  • inflammatory bowel disease,
  • Behçet’s disease,
  • psoriasis,
  • reactive arthritis, and
  • systemic lupus erythematosus,
  • Infections like: herpes infections, syphilis, Lyme disease, onchocerciasis, tuberculosis, and leprosy.

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

Specific therapy

Cycloplegics

  • 1% atropine
  • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle
  • Prevents the formation of synechiae
  • Reduces exudation

Steroids

  • Drug of choice in anterior uveitis
  • Reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect 

Systemic therapy 

  • Steroids
  • NSAIDs
  • Immunosuppressants
    • Used in severe cases

Related Pearl: Different types of keratic precipitates (KPs)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities are not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy. They are seen in the Preproliferative diabetic retinopathy stage.

Background diabetic retinopathy is a collective term used to describe the earliest changes in diabetic retinopathy. 

 Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins. These represent areas of nerve fiber infarcts. Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

Image shows cotton wool spots

questions.text: Treatment of ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome is:
questions.solution:
• Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner’s syndrome.
  • Frontalis suspension is done for congenital ptosis with poor elevation
  • Levator resection is done for moderate degrees of ptosis

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis

Surgery Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Fasanella Servat < 2 mm Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any Acquired ptosis
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata > 2 mm Congenital ptosis – Marcus Gunn ptosis

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
questions.solution:
The earliest changes seen on X-ray in MS are:

  • LA enlargement on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.
  • Straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette.
  • Posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA.
  • Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.

Enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium are commonly seen in patients with severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension.

Radiographic findings of mitral stenosis are:

  • Straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette
  • Prominence of the main pulmonary artery 
  • Dilation of the upper lobe pulmonary veins
  • Posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged left atrium.
  • Kerley B lines- These are dense, short, horizontal lines most frequently seen in lower and middle lung fields

Auscultatory findings in mitral stenosis

  • The first heart sound (S1) is accentuated
  • The opening snap (OS) is after A2 sound. It is best heard during the expiration and at the apex of the heart
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, which is heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position. This murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis.
  • If the patient also has mitral regurgitation, a systolic murmur can be heard at or medial to the apex. 

ECG tracing will show tall and peak T waves due to left atrial enlargement. It might also show the features of severe pulmonary hypertension, right axis deviation and RV hypertrophy.

Signs of left atrial enlargement:

  • Left atrial appendage (LAA) enlargement leading to straightening of left heart border – The left atrial appendage is the only portion of the left atrium that forms the part of the left heart border. Early or mild enlargement of the left atrium may be detected as enlargement of left atrial appendage. This is the earliest sign of Left atrial enlargement.
  • Posterior displacement of esophagus on lateral view (on barium swallow).
  • Double density sign or double atrial shadow on PA view.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination, you note areflexia and the speech is slurred. Which of the following would you administer to him as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive symmetric ascending weakness is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). The initial therapy is high-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg).

GBS is an acute autoimmune neuropathy. It results from the autoimmune destruction of nerves in the peripheral nervous system causing weakness that can progress to paralysis. It is associated with Campylobacter jejuni gastrointestinal infections, vaccines and respiratory illnesses. The antibodies target peripheral nerves and cause demylenation. Hence the preferred treatment is to neutralize these autoantibodies using IVIg (I.V. immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis. IVIg is often the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

IVIg is also preferred over plasma exchange (PE) for the AMAN and MFS variants of GBS.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. Areflexia or hyporeflexia is usually present. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling. Respiration is compromised when it involves respiratory muscles. In such cases, ventilatory support is needed.

Note: Steroid therapy is used in Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy and not useful in GBS. Physostigmine is used to treat mysthenia gravis which present initially with occular symptoms like ptosis and diplopia.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema​. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of right heart failure.

Heart failure may be either right-sided or left-sided. Sometimes, patients may have both types. In right-sided failure, patients typically have symptoms of fluid overload such as edema and hepatic congestion, while in left-sided failure they have symptoms of low cardiac output and elevated pulmonary venous pressure. Patients present with shortness of breath and exertional dyspnoea.

Signs of heart failure include:

  • Tachycardia, hypotension, low pulse pressure
  • Elevated JVP
  • Examination of the respiratory system may reveal crackles at lung bases due to transudation of fluid into the alveoli. Expiratory wheezes and Ronchi may be heard. Bibasilar dullness may be present due to pleural effusion.
  • Examination of the thyroid may reveal hyper or hypothyroidism.
  • Hepatic enlargement, ascites and peripheral pitting edema in patients with right heart failure.
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux, which is defined as an increase in JVP by 1cm due to sustained moderate pressure applied over the liver.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following is true with respect to this lesion?

choices.text: Vascular lesions characterised by the tortuous constriction of arterioles
Fill from the outer to center on applying and releasing pressure over the lesion
Seen in estrogen-deficient states such as emergency pill use and pregnancy
Mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease

questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi and it is mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease.

Spider naevi (nevus araneus) are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use.
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease, and
  • Thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis(thrush) is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, bronchi, trachea, or lungs is an AIDS-defining illness.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: The ascitic fluid analysis of a patient shows SAAG >1.1 g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL. The most likely etiology of ascites in this patient is
questions.solution:
SAAG >1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dl is seen in ascites due to cirrhosis.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of chronic crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, the passage of mucus in the stools, and tenesmus. Endoscopic examination reveals multiple lesions in the rectum and rectosigmoid which are continous without any normal mucosa in between. The mucosa appears red and has a fine granular surface like sandpaper.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis. 

Macroscopic appearance of ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is a mucosal disease and can cause proctitis, proctocolitis, and colitis. The affected mucosa appears erythematous and has a fine granular surface resembling sandpaper. In more severe diseases, the mucosa is hemorrhagic, edematous, and ulcerated. In long-standing disease, inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) may be present as a result of epithelial regeneration. The involvement of the mucosa is continuous without any normal mucosa in between.

Microscopic appearance of UC

The inflammatory process is limited to mucosa and submucosa. There is a distortion of the crypt architecture. The crypt may be bifid and reduced in number. There is a gap between the crypt base and muscularis mucosae. The neutrophils invade the crypts leading to cryptitis and crypt abscesses.

There might be basal plasma cells and multiple basal lymphoid aggregates.

Mucosal vascular congestion, with edema and focal hemorrhage, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages may be present.

It might also affect the ileum causing back wash ileitis which has villous atrophy and crypt regeneration with increased inflammation, increased neutrophil and mononuclear inflammation in the lamina propria, and patchy cryptitis and crypt abscesses.

Below image shows pseudopolyps in ulcerative colitis.

Below image shows the histology of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of transudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Superior vena cava obstruction causes transudative pleural effusion.

Transudative Pleural Effusion Exudative Pleural Effusion
Alteration in systemic factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid. Alteration in local factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid.
Causes include congestive cardiac failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, peritoneal dialysis, SVC obstruction, myxedema. Causes include neoplastic conditions like mesothelioma; infectious diseases like tuberculosis; pulmonary embolization; GI conditions like esophageal perforation, pancreatic diseases; collagen vascular diseases like SLE; asbestosis, sarcoidosis; drug-induced; hemothorax and chylothorax, etc.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease
  • Pulmonary embolization
  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration.  However, on ​administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of hypothyroidism and the TSH levels are low due to low levels of TRH. This is based on the fact that the administration of TRH increased the TSH levels. Hence, the patient has hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus.

Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. 

Low TSH levels may be seen in the following cases:

Disease Pathogenesis Presentation
Hyperthyroidism Feedback inhibition of TSH release Symptoms of hyperthyroidism
Primary disease of the pituitary Decreased release of TSH, thereby causing a decreased release of thyroid hormones

Symptoms of hypothyroidism.

Administration of TRH does not elevate the TSH levels in this case since the pituitary gland is abnormal
Primary disease of the hypothalamus Decreased release of TRH leading to decreased TSH and hypothyroidism Administration of TRH causes elevation of TSH levels since the pituitary gland is normal.

questions.text: A patient with marfanoid habitus, hyperparathyroidism, and neuromas of the tongue presents with a cervical mass.  The most likely cause of the cervical mass is_______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid which occurs in the setting of MEN 2B.

Medullary carcinoma is seen in both in MEN 2A and 2B. The RET gene is abnormally activated. In Hirschsprung disease, it is deactivated.

MEN 2B: It is characterized by multiple mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid appearance, medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, gastrointestinal ganglioneuromatosis, and thickened corneal nerves. This rare syndrome is inherited in an autosomal-dominant pattern.

Medullary carcinomas arising in the context of MEN-2B are generally more aggressive and metastasize more frequently.

MEN syndromes:

  • The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases, resulting in proliferative lesions (hyperplasia, adenomas, and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors.
  • Tumors arise in multiple endocrine organs, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).
MEN1 MEN 2 (previously MEN2A) MEN 3 (previously MEN 2B) MEN 4
Wermer's Syndrome Sipple's Syndrome Mucosal neuromata with endocrine tumors due to mutation in CDKN1B.
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pancreas tumors
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Medullary thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Ganglioneuromatosis

Similar to MEN 1 plus

  • Reproductive organ tumors (e.g. testicular tumors, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma)
  • Adrenal + Renal tumors

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

Known as Sipple’s syndrome

Chromosome 10 / RET gene

Associated conditions :

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

Known commonly as MEN 3

Chromosome 10/ RET gene

Features

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Associated abnormalities (40–50%)
    • Mucosal neuromas
    • Marfanoid habitus
    • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
    • Megacolon

questions.text: A 33-year-old unvaccinated female now presents with worsening shortness of breath, cough, and myalgias for the last 4 days. She also reports a loss of smell and taste. On examination, temperature is 103 deg F, pulse rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 33/minute and SpO2 is 87% on room air. CT scan of this patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with respiratory rate >30/min, SpO2 <90 % on room air along with the CT findings of bilateral, peripheral ground-glass opacity associated with smooth interlobular and intralobular septal thickening (crazy-paving pattern) is suggestive of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

The following table classifies COVID-19 based on severity - 

  Mild Moderate Severe
Features URTI and/or fever without shortness of breath or hypoxia

RR ≥ 24/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2: 90% to ≤93% on room air

RR > 30/min, breathlessness

OR

SpO2 < 90% on room air

 
  Home isolation and care Admit in ward Admit in ICU
Management Physical distancing, indoor mask use, strict hand hygiene, symptomatic management, monitoring temperature, and oxygen saturation. Seek immediate medical attention if:
  • Difficulty breathing
  • High-grade fever/severe cough >5days

May consider

Inhalational Budesonide at a dose of 800mcg BD for 5 days to be given if fever and/or cough are persistent beyond 5 days of disease onset.

Oxygen support:

  • Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% for COPD patients)
  • Non-rebreathing face mask
  • Awake proning in all patients requiring supplemental O2 therapy

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.
  • Switch to the oral route if stable and/or improving

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Monitoring:

  • Clinical Monitoring - Work of breathing, Hemodynamic instability, Change in oxygen requirement.Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY If there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT 24 to 48 hourly. IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA use: Remdesivir

Respiratory support:

  • NIV in patients with increasing oxygen requirement, if work of breathing is low.
  • HFNC in patients with increasing oxygen requirement.
  • Intubation if high work of breathing/if NIV is not tolerated.
  • Conventional ARDS net protocol for ventilatory management.

Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy:

  • Inj. Methylprednisolone 1 to 2 mg/kg in 2 divided doses (or an equivalent dose of dexamethasone) for 5 to 10 days.

Anticoagulation:

  • Conventional dose prophylactic UH/LMWH (enoxaparin 0.5mg/kg per day SC)

Supportive measures:

  • Maintain euvolemia
  • If sepsis/septic shock, then manage as per existing protocol.

Monitoring:

  • Serial CXR; HRCT chest to be done ONLY if there is worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: CRP and D-dimer 24-48 hourly; CBC, RFT, LFT daily; IL-6 to be done if deteriorating.

EUA/Off label use: 

  • Remdesivir
  • Tocilizumab.

 

 

Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are:

  • Lymphopenia (reported in up to 90%)
  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated aminotransaminase levels
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels
  • Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)

Due to a hypercoagulable state, coagulation factors are consumed leading to prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.

Radiographic features:

Typical features for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19

  • Obligatory features:
    • Ground-glass opacities, with or without consolidation, in regions close to the visceral pleural lines, including the fissures
    • Multifocal bilateral distribution
  • Confirmatory patterns:
    • Ground glass regions
    • Unsharp, rounded shape
    • Sharp demarcation, outlining the shape of multiple adjacent pulmonary nodules
    • Crazy paving with visible intralobular lines
    • Patterns compatible with organizing pneumonia
    • Thickened vessels within parenchymal abnormalities

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a known case of COPD presents to a general physician with complaints of difficulty in breathing even with mild activities for the past 1 month. He has a chronic history of smoking with an estimated toll of 20 pack-years. Which of the following measures is least likely to improve the survival benefit in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Inhaled corticosteroids are least likely to improve the survival benefit in these patients.

The given CT image shows extensive emphysematous changes in the bilateral lungs.

Only the following three interventions have been demonstrated to improve the survival benefit in COPD patients.

  • Smoking cessation
  • Oxygen therapy in chronically hypoxemic patients
  • Lung volume reduction surgery in selected patients with emphysema.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought to the ER with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. History is significant for a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease and treatment with enalapril for the same. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
The history points to hyperkalemia as a potential diagnosis, while absent P waves and peaked T waves on the ECG indicate cardiac toxicity of potassium. The ECG findings constitute a medical emergency and immediate intravenous infusion of calcium gluconate is the first step in management.

ECG changes seen in association with varying levels of hyperkalemia (Normal Serum K+ 3.5-4.5 mEq/L) -

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L - Tall peaked T waves, short QT interval, ST-segment depression
  • 6.5-8.0 mEq/L - Peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, disappearing P waves, QRS widening
  • >8.0 mEq/L - Absent P waves, progressive QRS widening, fascicular/ bundle branch blocks

Management of hyperkalemia:

1) Cardiac stabilization:

With cardiac monitoring, IV infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate in 2-3 minutes reverses the cardiac depolarization blockade caused by hyperkalemia. This serves to prevent fatal arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia/arrest, asystole, and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation.

2) Displacement of potassium into cells:

The next step involves the administration of 10 units of intravenous regular insulin with/without iv dextrose (50 mL of 50% dextrose) based on monitored glucose concentrations. This serves to shift the potassium into the cells. Inhaled beta-2 agonists have an additive effect and can be used along with insulin.

IV bicarbonate is especially helpful with sustained administration over hours and if metabolic acidosis is associated with hyperkalemia.

3) Definitive removal of potassium from the body:

It is accomplished by using cation exchange resins, diuretics, and through dialysis.

A peaked T wave is the first ECG change in hyperkalemia, and with increasing potassium concentration, P waves are lost and QRS complexes widen, ultimately deteriorating into ventricular arrhythmias/asystole.

ECG given below depicts hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His arterial blood gas analysis reveals pH - 7.24; pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of medication overuse headache.

Medication overuse headache: 

It is also known as analgesic rebound headache, drug-induced headache, or medication-misuse headache. In this condition medications that are used for the treatment of headache becomes the cause for headaches. It usually resolves when the overuse is stopped.

Diagnostic criteria: According to ICHD-3(International Classification of Headache Disorders-3)

  • Headache occurring on ≥15 days/month in a patient with a pre-existing headache disorder
  • Regular overuse for >3 months of one or more drugs that can be taken for acute and/or symptomatic treatment of headache.
  • Not better accounted for by another ICHD-3 diagnosis.

Management: It includes the following steps:

  • Withdrawal of the overused medication
  • Rescue therapy or the treatment of withdrawal symptoms
  • Initiation of preventative therapy if required
  • Alternative symptomatic medication for future headaches

Other options:

Option B: Tension headache: It is a chronic headache syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight band-like discomfort. It can be episodic or chronic in nature. It is usually not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, photophobia, etc.

Option C: Chronic migraine: Diagnostic criteria for migraine headache is as follows: Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 hours in patients with normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for headache, and

At least 2 of the following features Plus at least 1 of the following features
Unilateral pain Nausea or vomiting
Throbbing pain Photophobia and phonophobia
Aggravation by movement  
Moderate or severe intensity  

Option D: Cluster headache: It is characterized by deep, excruciating, nonfluctuating pain which is usually retroorbital. The classical feature of this condition is its periodicity.  At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at almost the same hour every day.
Typically the patient has daily bouts of one or two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year. In between the clusters, there is a pain-free interval.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The rash visualized in the image is a malar rash. It is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Cutaneous manifestations seen in SLE are:

  • Acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (malar rash)
  • Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus- DLE (discoid rash)
  • Ulcerations in the oral mucosa
  • Alopecia- it is a non-scarring alopecia in the majority of the cases. However, patients with DLE will have scarring alopecia.

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-smith SLE
Anti-histone Drug-induced Lupus
Anti-U1 RNP Mixed connective tissue disease
Rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP Rheumatoid arthritis
Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows swan neck deformity, which is classically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. It is characterized by hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint. The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules. 

They are generally firm, non-tender, and adherent to periosteum, tendons, or bursae. They develop in areas of the skeleton subjected to repeated trauma or irritation such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They may also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Nodules are typically benign, but rarely they can be also be associated with infection, ulceration, and gangrene

Patients at a risk for developing extra-articular manifestations in rheumatoid arthritis have a history of cigarette smoking, have early onset of significant physical disability, and test positive for serum rheumatoid factor or anti-CCP antibodies.

Important extraarticular manifestations seen in rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Subcutaneous nodules- most common
  • Sjogren syndrome causing keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Pulmonary: Pleuritis is the most common pulmonary manifestation. It can also cause interstitial lung diseases.
  • Cardiac: Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation. Others are cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, etc.
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis
  • Hematologic- Normochromic normocytic anemia is the most common hematologic abnormality
  • This disease is commonly associated with coronary artery disease, carotid atherosclerosis, osteoporosis, and hypoandrogenism.
  • Felty's syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen in less than 1% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, the following clinical feature is seen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test
It is caused by deficiency of cortisol
Overnight 100mg-dexamethasone suppression test is used for diagnosis
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic purple striae which along with the clinical features of hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability suggest the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome which is caused by excess cortisol.

Diagnosis of Cushing’s disease:

  • 24-h urine free cortisol (UFC) is raised: This is used as a screening test
  • Overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism
  • Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease
  • Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  
  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about half are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Screening/Confirmatory Test for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (3x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8–9 a.m. after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 p.m.
  • Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/L
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L
  • Low dose Dexamethasone test – Best initial test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone q6h for 2 days

If a number of these tests are positive then a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome is confirmed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen from the last 20 years due to back pain. The following findings are seen during the peripheral smear. Which of the following is likely to be been seen in this patient?

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of an iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper GI Bleed as seen in this patient where it presents as anemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with chronic low back pain presented with a urinary tract infection. On examination, he has fatigue, confusion, pallor and bony tenderness.  Blood investigations reveal anaemia and monoclonal spike. X-ray of his skull is shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows lytic lesions in the skull. The given scenario describes  symptoms of hypercalcemia (fatigue, confusion), anaemia and monoclonal spike. All these features are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myelomas: Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:

  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years

Signs and symptoms

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
  • Renal failure
  • Anemia
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Other options:

Option A- Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia- It usually occurs in older adults in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (B cell neoplasm). The tumor cells undergo terminal differentiation to plasma cells which secrete monoclonal IgM that causes hyperviscocity syndrome. In this syndrome, light chains secretion very rarely lead to renal failure and bone destruction is not seen.

Option C- Cryoglobulinemia- It results in precipitation of macroglobulins at lower temperatures leading to Raynaud's phenomenon.

Option D- Senile systemic amyloidosis- It refers to systemic deposition of amyloid in elderly patients. The amyloid in this condition is derived from normal TTR (transthyretin). It usually involves the heart.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 30 g/L and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old laborer met with an accident while walking on a highway. He has been brought to the Emergency Medicine department where you are posted as an intern. He is confused, opens eyes spontaneously, and localizes to pain.  You would calculate the GCS score as _____
questions.solution:
Glasgow Coma Scale score for the above patient is 13.

For calculating the GCS:

The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused

The score for eye-opening: 4, because his eyes are opening spontaneously 

The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+4+5) = 13.

Glasgow Coma Scale(GCS) is used in the assessment of the head injury. Eye-opening, motor responses of the limbs, and verbal output are used to assess the GCS. These three responses have been found to be predictive of outcome in severe head injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete comes for a routine examination. He has no symptoms. The ECG is as shown below. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 45 bpm. The patient is an athlete and heart rates are usually lower in athletes.

As the patient is asymptomatic no further therapy should be given to increase the heart rate.

Sinus bradycardia:

  • Sinus bradycardia is defined as SA nodal rhythm with a rate <60 beats/min. However, in young healthy adults and athletes, a resting heart rate of <60 beats/min is common.
  • Also, a sinus pause of upto 3 seconds on ECG is commonly seen in athletes and elderly individuals.
  • If the rate is <40 beats/min, in an awake individual in the absence of physical training, then it is considered abnormal.

Diagnosis of SA node dysfunction:

  • The presence of abnormal sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is insufficient to diagnose SA node dysfunction. Longer-term electrocardiographic recording and clinical correlation are required to establish the diagnosis.
  • On the contrary, the presence of symptoms without any sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is sufficient to rule out SA node dysfunction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination there were soft heart sounds and JVP was increased. A transthoracic echocardiography revealed an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. Which of the following observations can we expect?
questions.solution:
Electrical alternans is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intra pericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

  • Tapping apical impulse is a sign of mitral stenosis.
  • Paradoxical respiration is a sign of flail chest (in rib fracture).
  • Friedreich’s diastolic collapse of the cervical veins, describes a sharp and deep y descent of the jugular venous waveform. Preservation of both the x and y descents of the jugular venous waveform in patients with constrictive pericarditis is a distinguishing feature from cardiac tamponade, in which the y descent is typically absent.

questions.text: The findings in the ECG given below are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
ST segment elevation (>1 mm) in the inferior leads II, III and aVF is seen in acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with the clinical sign elicited here ?
questions.solution:
The examination done by keeping the dorsal surfaces of the fingers opposed is to elicit clubbing. Irritable bowel syndrome is not associated with clubbing.

In a normal person, when the dorsal surfaces of the distal parts of two fingers are opposed, a diamond-shaped gap is created, called Schamroth's window.

Obliteration in clubbed fingers of the diamond-shaped window normally produced is called the Schamroth's sign.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The best step in management is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Wilson's disease can be diagnosed by performing the following investigations in the order shown below:

  1. Serum ceruloplasmin levels (screening) 
  2. Slit-lamp examination for KF ring
  3. 24-hour urine copper excretion 
  4. Liver biopsy and quantitative copper assay 

Baseline serum copper levels can be measured, but they have no role in diagnosis. They are more useful in determining response to treatment. Hence, serum ceruloplasmin is the appropriate answer.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor(shown in the gif in question)
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following findings will you not expect to see in a patient with SIADH?

choices.text: Normal serum urea and creatinine levels

questions.solution:
SIADH does not cause hypernatremia. SIADH is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water in the body. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt in the urine, leading to urine sodium level of > 20 mEq/L in these patients. Thus, the level of water reaches a steady state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur, giving rise to hyponatremia.

SIADH is characterized by low levels of uric acid, normal blood pressure, and normal urea and creatinine levels.

SIADH is diagnosed based on the following criteria (Bartter-Schwartz criteria):

  1. Reduced serum osmolality
    2. Urine osmolality > Serum osmolality
    3. Clinical euvolemia
    4. Increased levels of urinary sodium
    5. Absence of other causes of hyponatremia like pituitary, renal, adrenal, thyroid or liver diseases.
Condition Plasma osmolality Urine osmolality Plasma Sodium concentration
Central DI High Low Relative Hypernatremia
Nephrogenic DI High Low Relative Hypernatremia
Psychogenic polydipsia Low Low Hyponatremia
SIADH Low High Hyponatremia

questions.text: A patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis was treated with IV insulin along with a bolus of normal saline. The initial serum glucose concentration of 350 mg/dL dropped to 250 mg/dL after two hours. BP, pulse, and urine output are normal. Which of the following intravenous fluids is administered next?
questions.solution:
In this patient, half-normal saline with 5% dextrose is administered.

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, the normal saline infusion is replaced with half-normal saline infusion. It is done to prevent hyperchloremia that can develop from administering large volumes of saline needed to correct dehydration.

Additionally, 5% dextrose is added to half-normal saline when serum glucose concentration is 250 mg/dl and the glucose concentration is maintained between 150-200 mg/dl. This is done to avoid cerebral edema caused by a rapid change in plasma osmolality.

Steps in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis:

1) IV bolus of regular insulin (0.1 units/kg). Avoid insulin and correct potassium level first if below 3.3 meq/L. An IV bolus of normal saline until vitals become stable.

2) Titrate IV infusion of insulin according to a drop in serum glucose.

3) Once vitals are stable, switch to half normal saline. Once serum glucose concentration reaches 250 mg/dl, add 5% dextrose.

4) Treat underlying condition

5) Replace potassium loss and administer bicarbonate if acidosis is severe (pH < 7)

6) Switch to subcutaneous long-acting plus short-acting insulin regimen and wean from IV insulin infusion once a patient resumes eating.

questions.text: Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg is seen in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

Serological Patterns of Hepatitis B Infection:

Window period  - -   - + IgM
Chronic HBV(high infectivity) +  -  +   -  IgG
Chronic HBV(low infectivity) + -  -  +  IgG

Immunized (Natural infection) -  +  - -  IgG
Remote past infection -  -  -  -  IgG

questions.text: The device seen in the following image is____?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the figure is of a cardiac pacemaker. 

Cardiac pacemaker is a an electronic device kept under the skin that senses intrinsic heart rhythms and provides electrical stimulation when indicated.

In adults, permanent pacemakers are most commonly implanted with access to the heart by way of the subclavian–superior vena cava venous system.

The three types of cardiac pacemaking is 

  • Single-chamber pacemaker–one pacing lead is implanted in the right atrium or ventricle.

  • Dual-chamber pacemaker-two pacing leads are implanted (one in the right ventricle and one in the right atrium) which is the most common type of cardiac pacemaking.

  • Biventricular pacing (cardiac resynchronization therapy [CRT])- in addition to single-or dual-chamber right heart pacing leads, a lead is advanced to the coronary sinus for left ventricular epicardial pacing.

The most common indications for cardiac pacemaking:SA Node dysfunction , Carotid sinus hypersensitivity and vasovagal syncope.

In SA Node dysfunction some of the indications are :

  • symptomatic bradycardia or sinus pause
  • due to essential long-term drug
    therapy.
  • symptomatic chronotropic incompetence
  • atrial fibrillation with bradycardia and pauses >5 
  • syncope of unknown origin

Complications:

1.Acute 

  • infection
  • hematoma
  • pneumothorax
  • cardiac perforation
  • diaphragmatic/phrenic nerve stimulation
  • lead dislodgment

2.Chronic

  • infection
  • erosion
  • lead failure

Rotation of the pacemaker pulse generator in its subcutaneous pocket is referred to as “twiddler’s syndrome” can wrap the leads around the generator and produce dislodgment with failure of the pacemaker.

Enhancements in battery technology and component design have produced a pacing system small enough to be implanted in the heart without the need for a transvenous lead.

questions.text:

  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block

questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-B, 2-D,3-A,4-C.

The different types of heart blocks are:

1.First Degree Heart Block: Prolonged PR > 0.2s, RR interval equal

2. Second Degree Heart Block:  missed QRS

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach: Progressive prolongation of PR interval, missed QRS
  • Mobitz type 2: fixed PR interval, missed QRS

3. Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS
