questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the modified Duke criteria for a definitive diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis
The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established
Presence of 1 major + 2 minor is definitive endocarditis in clinical criteria

questions.solution:
If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major (or) 1 major + 3 minor (or) 5 minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: Prophylactic cranial irradiation is given for which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cranial irradiation is given in lung cancer, more specifically small cell carcinoma of lung.

Prophylactic cranial irradiation(PCI) is given to  either LD-SCLC(limited disease small cell lung carcinoma) or ED-SCLC(end stage small cell lung carcinoma) who have responded well to initial therapy.

In LD-SCLC patients complete remission is seen while in ED-SCLC the occurence of symptomatic brain metastases is decreased and prolonged disease free interval compared to when no PCI.

Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is the most aggressive type of lung cancer.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A patient with head and neck cancer was told by his oncologist that needs radiotherapy at a total dose of  70 Gy over a 7 week period for his tumor. He was scheduled to receive a dose of 1.8-2Gy per fraction, once daily over 5 days a  week, for 7 weeks. What is this type of radiotherapy called as?
questions.solution:
Since the patient needs 70Gy in total for his tumour and his dose per fraction is at 1.8-2.0 Gy, 5 days a week, for 7 weeks, it is called Regular/Conventional Fractionated Radiotherapy.

Radiotherapy:

The total dose of radiation needed for a tumour is usually given as fractions over the entire treatment period as it maximises the effects of the radiation on the malignant cells and minimises the damage on the healthy cells.

The reasons for this are due to :

1. Re-distribution: Cells are more resistant to damage in the late S2 phase while sensitive in the M and G2 phase. Only some tumour cells will be in the sensitive phase of the cell cycle when the radiation is given. Hence, giving another dose at a later time helps in killing the other cells who were in the resistant part of the cell cycle, thus increasing the success rate of the therapy.

2. Re-oxygenation: Hypoxic cells are less sensitive to the indirect effects of radiation. The tumour cells which are closer to oxygen sources are killed first and in the intervening time, the other relatively hypoxic cells can improve their oxygenation so that the next fraction of radiation is effective on them. 

3. Repair: The ability to repair DNA is more for healthy cells than malignant cells and thus when a radiation dose has been received, the healthy cells repair their DNA faster than the malignant cells. The malignant cells whose DNA is not fully repaired are highly susceptible to the next dose of radiation. 

 

Types of fractionation:

In the case of Head and neck cancer, the conventional schedule of radiotherapy involves the delivery of 70 Gy in 1.8-2 Gy fractions(total around 35-36 fractions) over 7 weeks, treating 5 days per week.

However, this dose can be delivered at 1.10-1.25 Gy/fraction for 56 fractions over the same time period of 7 weeks which is called hyperfractionation. This delivers a lower dose with more fractions and the efficacy improves as the healthy cells have more ability to repair themselves in the intervening time. 

Accelerated fractionation is when the same 70 Gy, is given at around 1.6-1.8 Gy/fraction but it is delivered more than once daily, decreasing the total treatment time to around 6 weeks. These aim to decrease tumor proliferation which can lead to failure of the therapy. 

Note:

Shorter schedules remain useful for small-volume treatments: 50 Gy in 16 fractions over 3 weeks or 55 Gy in 20 fractions over 4 weeks.

Accelerated schedules although is easier to implement than hyperfractionation result in a lesser survival gain.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common delayed symptom of head and neck radiation therapy?
questions.solution:
The most common delayed symptom of head and neck radiation therapy is xerostomia.

Complications of Radiotherapy

  • Xerostomia- most common
  • Mucositis
  • Temporary or permanent dysgeusia (altered taste perception)
  • Osteoradionecrosis which is related to tooth caries and results from decreased production of saliva and damage to microvasculature of mandible and maxilla.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about chemoradiotherapy (CRT) except:

choices.text: Radiotherapy component also acts as radio-sensitizing agent
Chemotherapy mainly helps in reducing distant metastases
Radiotherapy mainly results in disease control locally

questions.solution:
Chemotherapy component of the CRT acts as radio-sensitizing agent.

Chemoradiotherapy (CRT) is the combination of chemotherapy with radiotherapy.

  • CRT can be of two types: concurrent, where both chemotherapy and radiotherapy are given simultaneously; or sequential, where they are given one after the other.
  • The chemotherapy component acts as the radio-sensitizing agent.
  • In various cancers, chemoradiotherapy has shown to be effective as neoadjuvant therapy before the surgery.
  • The radiotherapy mainly results in the local disease control, while the chemotherapy component, mainly helps in reducing the chances of distant metastases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

Primary survey is used to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control haemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit.
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine, chest AP view and pelvis AP view are done when necessary.
  • When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

A - Hypovolaemic; B - Obstructive; C - Cardiogenic; D - Distributive
A - Obstructive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Hypovolaemic; D - Distributive
A - Distributive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Obstructive; D - Hypovolaemic

questions.solution:
The correct match is as below:

  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance Mixed venous saturation Base deficit
Hypovolemic Low Low High Low High
Obstructive Low High High Low High
Cardiogenic Low High High Low High
Distributive High Low Low High High

Hypovolemic shock - 
It is due to reduced circulating volume. Causes include hemorrhage, dehydration, vomiting, third spacing.

Obstructive Shock -
Leads to a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus, or air embolus.

Cardiogenic shock - 
Due to the failure of the heart to pump blood to tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury, and cardiomyopathy

Distributive shock - 
Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance leading to vasodilation. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include spinal shock, anaphylaxis, and septic shock. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: According to the CEAP classification, what will be your scoring in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb varicose veins, and is classified as C2A according to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders.

According to the CEAP classification, the clinical classification of venous disease is as follows:

For clinical classification:
● C0: no signs of venous disease;
● C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins;
● C2: varicose veins;
● C3: edema;
● C4a: pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare);
● C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche;
● C5: healed venous ulcer;
● C6: active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further characterized depending upon whether the patient is symptomatic (S) or asymptomatic (A). Since the above options do not contain (S), the best answer would be C2A amongst the given choices.

Varicose veins is a condition in which there is tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as swelling in the lower limbs, with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb.

Diagnosis is made using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS).

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

to chronic venous disease

*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts subcuticular sutures.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either absorbable or non-absorbable suture material may be used.

There are four frequently used suture techniques.

Interrupted:  the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and then passed through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at the right angle.

The distance from the entry point of the needle to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured, and each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart (2x).

 

Continuous: The first suture is placed in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound.

 

Mattress: Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal and are used for the eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

The initial suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture, but then the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound.

questions.text: The image below shows a post-mastectomy patient, with swelling of the upper limb.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. 

Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.

Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.

Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.

Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters.Subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet.Painful swelling of the arm is observed.

Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.text: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goitre is via:
questions.solution:
The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goitre is via the neck.

Retrosternal goitre can be of two types:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre - due to the overgrowth of ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum. Blood supply is from mediastinal vessels.
  • Secondary mediastinal goitre - slow growth of thyroid tissue from the neck that extends to the retrosternal region. Blood supply is from thyroid vessels. 

Retrosternal goitre presents with dyspnoea, stridor and dilated neck veins. Pemberton’s sign is seen i.e., facial or conjunctival congestion seen on raising of hands above the head. CECT is done to assess the extent. 

Indications for median sternotomy:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux
<75% relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
It is is a primary motility disorder

questions.solution:
The given barium swallow showing bird beak appearance is suggestive of Achalasia cardia.  The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. There is incomplete(<75%) relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter

Manometry is considered the most sensitive investigation to diagnose achalasia as it identifies early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.

Endoscopy is useful for ruling out pseudoachalasia.

Note: 24 hours pH monitoring is ideal and most accurate in patients with the features of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

Related Pearl: Complications of Appendicectomy

  • Wound infection: 5–10%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess: 8%
  • Post operative ileus
  • Respiratory complications
  • Venous thrombo-embolism
  • Portal pyemia- septicemia in portal venous system, can lead to hepatic abscess.
  • Adhesive intestinal obstruction: 1–3% (MC late post op complication)
  • Fecal fistula
  • Port site hernias.
  • Appendico-cutaneous fistula or appendico-vesical fistula: rare
  • Mortality after appendicectomy is less than 1%

questions.text: A  young office executive, on tour presents with complaints of abdominal pain and painless bright red bleeding in stools for the past 1 week. External and per rectal examinations are normal. As attending general practitioner what will be your next step?
questions.solution:
Next step would be proctoscopy to rule out common causes of bleeding PR like haemorrhoids. Internal hemorrhoids cannot be palpated and can be best diagnosed by proctoscopy.

Proctoscopy is a procedure used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction and lower rectum (upto 10 cm). Biopsy of suspicious area can be taken if needed.

Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:

  • Rectal bleeding
  • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhoea
  • Pain or difficulty in defecation
  • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external haemorrhoids
  • Rectal prolapse.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal Hemorrhoids

External Hemorrhoids

Located proximal to the dentate line

Painless, can be ligated

Banding is preferred

Also known as a 5-day, painful, self-curing lesion

Located distal to the dentate line

Painful, not ligated

Excision is done

Repeated thrombosis leads to semi-ripe black currant appearance

questions.text: A  27 year old male presents with multiple hemangioblastomas,pheochromocytoma,multiple renal and pancreatic cysts with similar problems in his brother, aunt, and father.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of multiple hemangioblastomas,pheochromocytoma,multiple renal and pancreatic cysts with family history is most likely to be von Hippel- Lindau disease.

It is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by the development of highly vascularized tumors in multiple organs. These include:

  • Haemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cysts- develop into clear renal cell cancer.
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Ovary cystadenoma
  • Epididymal cystadenoma

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Etiology and risk factors- 

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis(like a clapper in a bell). Most common cause.
  • Inversion of the testis.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are - scrotal pain and swelling, erythema, negative cremasteric reflex, nausea, and vomiting, testis seems high in the scrotum and twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Management is determined primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false-positives are high and hence not routinely recommended. Urgent scrotal exploration is indicated if there is doubt regarding the diagnosis. A transverse scrotal incision is taken and if the testis is viable twisting again is prevented by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe.

Differential diagnosis -

  • Epididymo-orchitis - Here dysuria associated with the accompanying urinary infection is commonly present. In epididymo-orchitis elevation of the testis reduces the pain while it makes it worse in torsion. 
  • Torsion of a testicular appendage - Here the most common structure to twist is the appendix of the testis and it can be visible as a small dark spot. In most cases, it is indistinguishable from torsion testis. Hence in cases of doubt surgical exploration is done.

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because of the involvement of the superficial femoral artery in chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain signifies critical limb ischemia, occurring due to the worsening of perfusion to the muscle.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The highest pressure is in the dorsalispedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery that serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.5 Rest pain
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

The contents of a direct hernia protrude medially to the inferior epigastric artery. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. Despite the differences in origin, the management of both hernias is done by a Lichenstein repair.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of  the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for repair a hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done
     

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect inguinal hernia:

questions.text: Which of the statements are incorrect regarding roux-en-Y gastric bypass in bariatric surgery?

choices.text: The roux limb is longer than the biliary limb
Bowel continuity is maintained by jejunojejunostomy
The roux limb can be retrocolic or antecolic
Gastric pouch is created along the greater curvature

questions.solution:
Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature in the roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass for bariatric surgery:

A small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature
↓ 
A roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy;
↓ 
Restrictive + Malabsorptive mechanism
↓ 
Weight loss

Note:

  • Biliary limb is usually kept short (30-50 cm) in order to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies.
  • The roux limb can be retro-colic or antecolic

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.solution:
The image below shows a case of carbuncle on the back of head which is a common location.

Carbuncle:

  • A carbuncle is a deep infection of a group of contiguous follicles with S. aureus.
  • Intense inflammatory changes in the surrounding and underlying connective tissues, including the subcutaneous fat.
  • Larger than abscesses/boils as they represent a cluster of coalescing boils connected under the skin surface.
  • Risk factors include diabetes, malnutrition, cardiac failure, drug addiction, obesity and prolonged steroid therapy.
  • Smooth painful hard red lump, dome‐shaped and increases in size to reach a diameter of 3–10 cm or more.
  • Suppuration begins after some 5–7 days, and pus is discharged from the multiple follicular orifices.
  • Necrosis of the intervening skin leaves a yellow slough surmounting a crateriform nodule and can even develop into a deep ulcer with a purulent floor.
  • Most commonly on the back of the neck, the shoulders or the hips and thighs.
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever,malaise and prostration can be present if severe.
  • In the frail and ill, death may occur from toxaemia or from metastatic infection while in favourable cases lesions they usually heal with scarring.
  • Treatment includes antibiotics, incision and drainage or saucerization under local anaesthetic to help remove pus and necrotic tissue and expedite healing

 

Option A: Botryomycosis presents as multiple indurated draining sinuses mimicking actinomycosis.

Option B: Ecthyma is a pyogenic infection of the skin characterized by the formation of adherent crusts, beneath which ulceration occurs. It most commonly results from mixed infection of group A streptococci > staphylococci and causes a deeper infection than impetigo. The buttocks, thighs, and legs are most commonly affected.

Option C: In erysipelas, well-defined raised margin erythematous lesions are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following zones of retroperitoneum need mandatory surgical exploration as management?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 needs mandatory surgical exploration.

Retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma:

Zone1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done.

Mattox maneuver is left medial visceral rotation to expose the aorta.

Cattell-Braasch maneuver is done by right medial visceral rotation to expose IVC.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum.

It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, maternal polyhydramnios, etc.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (option A) will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble).

Jejunal atresia (option B) on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Condition
Findings
Duodenal atresia
Double bubble sign (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Jejunal and ileal atresia
Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Sigmoid volvulus
Coffee bean sign (plain erect X-ray abdomen)
Achalasia cardia
Bird-beak sign (barium swallow)

questions.text: What is the most common electrolyte abnormality associated with paralytic ileus?
questions.solution:
Paralytic ileus is a type of adynamic obstruction and the most common electrolyte abnormality seen is hypokalemia.

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • With associated distension: marked and tympanitic
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary)

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

Note:

The return of normal motility occurs in the following temporal sequence:

Small intestine (within the first 24 hours) → Stomach (within 48 hours) → Colonic motility (3 to 5 days)

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER after suffering a blow to the head with a cricket ball. The patient was unconscious on arrival. After some time, the patient regained his consciousness and then he again started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT scan was done and the image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of a lesion in the lower eyelid. She says that the lesion was initially like a bump and now it is ulcerated. On examination, an ulcerative lesion with raised and pearly white edge is seen in the lower eyelid of the right eye. The biopsy was taken from the lesion and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of cell nests. In the periphery of the cell nest, the cells are arranged in the palisading pattern. This is diagnostic of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma is the malignant tumor of the epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Naevoid.

Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other options:

Option A- Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns).

The microscopy of SCC consists of irregular masses of squamous epithelium. They may show keratin production.

Below image shows the microscopic appearance of SCC.

Option B- Marjolin's ulcer- It is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that appears on a pre-existing scar.

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum consists of multiple pink pruritic papules on the skin and mucous membranes with central umbilication. Microscopically it shows the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions in the cells of stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.

Below images show the macroscopic and microscopic appearance of molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the epigastric region, and there is no palpable mass. Which of the following is the most specific and reliable marker for diagnosing acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The scenario is reflective of acute pancreatitis, the enzyme most reliable for the diagnoss is serum lipase.

Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of clinical findings + an elevated levels of pancreatic enzyme in the plasma. If the elevation of amylase and lipase levels is threefold or higher, then the diagnosis of pancreatitis is confirmed.

Serum lipase levels is a more sensitive indicator to establish the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis in patients who present 48 hours after the onset of symptoms. Lipase is also a more specific marker of acute pancreatitis because serum amylase levels can be elevated in a other conditions, like peptic ulcer disease, mesenteric ischemia, salpingitis, and macroamylasemia. 

Other options:

Option A - Serum creatinine, primarily a marker of kidney function, can be affected in severe pancreatitis due to complications like dehydration or kidney injury. However, it's not directly reflective of the pancreatic inflammation itself.

Option B - Serum amylase, while often measured, lacks sensitivity and specificity. It can be elevated in other conditions like salivary gland problems, bowel obstruction, or even kidney disease.

Option D - Serum bilirubin is elevated in acute biliary pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

Sentinel loop sign: Generalized or local ileus, with isolated dilation of a segment of the gut (sentinel loop) consisting of jejunum, transverse colon, or duodenum adjacent to the pancreas

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: What is the size(in F) of a Foley catheter having a white-colored ring in the baloon port ?
questions.solution:
A Foley's catheter having a white colored ring in the ballon port, is 12 F.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition given below?

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene.

Clinical features are scrotal pain, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, bilateral orchidectomy is not performed. It is also called "shameful exposure of the testis". 

Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. When the infection has been controlled, vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy has no role in Fournier's gangrene.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with low backache and weight loss.He has progressive difficulty in urination and had an episode of urinary retention 2 days back which was relieved by catheterization.PSA was done which was  5.2 ng/ml and X Ray LS spine shows osteoblastic changes. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details with elevated PSA and blastic changes in LS spine suggest a diagnosis of carcinoma prostate.The Xray findings can be metastasis to the bone.

Carcinoma of the prostate:

  • It is the most common form of cancer affecting men, usually older than 50 years of age.
  • The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes.
  • Men with germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 have a 20-fold increased risk of prostate cancer.
  • Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes and mutations or deletions that activate the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.
  • Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.
  • Approximately 70% of carcinomas of the prostate arise in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location.
  • Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination.
  • Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent.
  • Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.
  • Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

PSA is a product of prostatic epithelium secreted in the semen. Normally, only minute amounts of PSA circulates in the serum. Older men have a higher serum PSA level than younger men, so the normal range varies with age.

Measurement of serum PSA levels is widely used to assist the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer.

Age Upper age-specific PSA(ng/mL)
40–49 yrs 2.5
50–59 yrs 3.5
60–69 yrs 4.5
70–79 yrs 6.5

Prostatic biopsy specimen showing foci of small crowded glands, some showing cribriform pattern of arrangement.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of the Alvarado score for the diagnosis of appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Elevated BP is not a component of the Alvarado score for the diagnosis of appendicitis.

The components of the Alvarado scoring system can be remembered using the mnemonic MANTRELS

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

Related Pearl: Signs in appendicitis

Sign

Characteristic

Seen in

Dunphy’s sign

Pain on coughing

Acute appendicitis

Rovsing sign

 

Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant

Acute appendicitis

Obturator sign

Pain on internal rotation of hip

Pelvic appendicitis

Ilio-Psoas sign

Pain on extension of hip

Retrocaecal appendicitis

Aaron sign

Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point

Acute appendicitis

Basseler sign

Sharp pain created by compressing appendix between abdominal wall and iliacus

Chronic appendicitis

Blumberg’s sign

Transient abdominal wall rebound tenderness

Peritoneal inflammation

Ten Horn sign

 Pain caused by gentle traction of right testicle

Appendicitis

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of urethra and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury?
questions.solution:
History of a blow to the perineum and swelling of penis and scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents. 

Clinical features of bulbar urethral injury: 

  • perineal bruising, 
  • hematoma (butterfly distribution)
  • bleeding from the urethral meatus 
  • retention of urine 

Option A: Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture. Pelvic fracture is most commonly caused by road traffic accidents. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and on digital rectal examination, there will be high overriding prostrate.

Option C: Prostatic urethral injury occurs secondary to pelvic fracture. Clinical features are the same as membranous urethral injury.

Option D: Urinary bladder rupture can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is most common. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a painless lump on the upper side of her left breast following an injury.  On examination,  the breast is slightly tender. Skin tethering, and nipple retraction are also present. Which of the following helps to differentiate between traumatic fat necrosis and carcinoma of the breast?
questions.solution:
A biopsy is required to differentiate traumatic fat necrosis from carcinoma of the breast.

Traumatic fat necrosis mimics breast carcinoma. As it may present with:

  • Skin tethering
  • Nipple retraction
  • Lump in the breast(often painless).
  • Mammographic densities or calcifications

Histologically, fat necrosis is composed of lipid-laden macrophages, scar tissue, and chronic inflammatory cells.

Grossly ill-defined, firm, gray-white nodules containing small chalky-white foci are seen.

The mammogram shows egg-shell calcification. It has no malignant potential.

Note: A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump and biopsy is required for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the ER after RTA, his RR is 25/min, BP is 80/45mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the left side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the given chest radiograph are suggestive of pneumothorax. It is managed by inserting wide-bore needle in 5th ICS followed by placing an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS.

Tension pneumothorax and simple pneumothorax have similar signs, symptoms, and examination findings, but hypotension qualifies the pneumothorax as a tension pneumothorax.

Immediate management includes inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line.

Definitive management includes insertion of the intercostal tube in the triangle of safety. If a sucking wound is present, then it is covered with gauze pieces and taped on 3 sides.

Remember: (Acc to ATLS 10th edition)

  • In adults, needle thoracotomy location changed to 5th ICS mid axillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the thoracotomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

An intercostal tube is placed in the triangle of safety which is the safest site for insertion of a drain that lies in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line, above the level of the nipple, and, below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

Inserting and managing a chest drain:

Insertion of an intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is the standard management.

The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the Triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient from a lower strata economy presents with mild fever which is present only during the night and associated weight loss. She has a swelling on her neck as shown in the image below which is soft, non-tender and fluctuation is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of immunosuppression, symptoms of fever at night, weight loss, and the neck finding of an ulcer with undermined edges is suggestive of tubercular lymphadenitis.

The image shows long-standing tubercular adenitis with a sinus. 

Tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis:

  • Any group of lymph nodes can be involved.
  • Symptoms include evening pyrexia, malaise, cough (from pulmonary tuberculosis) while in children-failure to thrive can be seen. 
  • A matted lymph nodal mass is the typical clinical feature.
  • In later stages the mass may be cystic, denoting an abscess.
  • The abscess denotes underlying caseation and does not show any features of inflammation – hence it is called a 'cold abscess'.
  • The pus is initially confined by the deep cervical fascia, but after weeks or months, this may become eroded at one point and the pus flows through the small opening into the space beneath the superficial fascia. The process has now reached the stage of a ‘collar stud abscess'.
  • An abscess may burst through the skin to form an ulcer with undermined edges which is typical of a tubercular ulcer with undermined edges and can develop into a discharging sinus.
  • Diagnosis is by the culture of pus and biopsy of the lymph node.
  • The involvement of other systems must be excluded.
  • Treatment-Antitubercular drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following steps will not be done in a modified radical mastectomy ?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss).

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor divided
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

PCNL is the treatment of choice for large renal stones of a diameter more than 2cm. PCNL is indicated in the following types of renal calculi:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stone: >1 cm
  • Morbidly obese individuals in whom ESWL is contraindicated

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

  • Haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy: 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Other stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL include cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones.

ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially in cases of insufficient disintegration.

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note:

Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse  (a german word, which means 'street of stones'). The most common site of the column of stone fragments obstruction is the distal ureter, followed by the proximal ureter and mid ureter.The postoperative image is attached below.

 

Ureteroscopic removal:

Semi-rigid ureteroscopes are frequently used to directly visualise ureteric calculi. Advances in the design of ureterorenoscopy have rendered the entire urinary tract accessible to endoscopic examination.  Stones can also be fragmented using mechanical disintegration using the lithoclast.

These are generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. 

The most significant complications relate to injury to the ureteric mucosa or wall and include ureteric perforation and extravasation, avulsion of the ureter and ureteric stricture.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy. 

 

Open surgery:

A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. 

Also, in extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated, one might resort to take up the patient for open/laparascopic surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness,fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and contralateral breast is normal.What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and Drainage after confirming with an ultrasound
Broad spectrum antibiotics only  after confirming with an ultrasound
Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics - Repeated aspiration if necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscess.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

 

Image (above) shows mastitis of the breast

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumours is radioresistant?
questions.solution:
Metastasis to bone are generally radiosensitive, except for Renal cell carcinoma which is conventionally regarded as radioresistant.

In patients aged more than 50 years, metastatic bone tumors are more common than primary bone tumors. It should be suspected in any lytic bone lesion. Osteoblastic lesions are uncommon and seen in prostate carcinoma. Primary tumors are most often found in breast, prostate, kidney, lung, thyroid, bladder and GIT. These metastasize to the vertebra, pelvis, femur and humerus.

It presents more often as only pain or may be discovered incidentally in a pathological fracture. Treatment is usually a combination of chemoradiation and surgery. Bauer's criteria define the prognosis, the more the score, the better the prognosis.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

  RADIOSENSITIVE

   RADIORESISTANT

Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which are radioresistant)

Osteosarcoma

Ewing’s Sarcoma

Chondrosarcoma

Multiple myeloma

Fibrosarcoma

Lymphoma

Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except:

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Physiological changes in pregnancy

Clinical examination

  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • Occassional S3at Mitral area
  • Aortic or pulmonary flow murmurs at aortic/pulmonary areas
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • S1 M increased and widely split

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Pregnancy does not alter voltage
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and
  • Increased left ventricular mass

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)
