questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole that is cephalic or podalic-occupies with the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the fetal orientation. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities. By noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly, fetal orientation can be determined.
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip/1st pelvic grip): It assesses the presenting part. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (2nd pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

choices.text: Prevention of Seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby.

Magnesium sulfate administered parenterally is an effective anticonvulsant that avoids producing central nervous system depression. It may be given intravenously by continuous infusion or intramuscularly by intermittent injection. Magnesium sulfate has a neuroprotective effect

It reduces contractility of the uterus and can be used as a tocolytic.

MgSo4 is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach. Very low-birthweight neonates whose mothers were treated with magnesium sulfate for preterm labor or preeclampsia were found to have a reduced incidence of cerebral palsy at 3 years.

questions.text: A patient underwent a one-step procedure for gestational diabetes screening. Which of the following results indicate a positive result?
questions.solution:
According to WHO and ADA guidelines, a patient with 2-hour blood glucose of ≥153  mg/dl is considered to have gestational diabetes mellitus. 

In one-step procedure, the patient is given 75g of glucose after an overnight fast, and blood glucose is measured hourly every 2 hours. 

Diagnostic criteria with one-step 2 hr are as follows:

  • Fasting ≥ 92 mg/dL 
  • 1-hour ≥ 180 mg/dL 
  • 2-hour ≥ 153 mg/dL

In two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separate steps.

Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. If it is ≥140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done.

Step 2 - patient is given 100g of glucose and values measured hourly, for 3 hours. A diagnosis is made if at least two values are high using one of two methods:

  • Fasting ≥ 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/l)
  • 1-hour ≥ 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/l)
  • 2-hour ≥ 155 mg/dL (8.6 mmol/l)
  • 3-hour ≥ 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/l)

Note: One-step is a simple diagnostic test but identifies more women with gestational diabetes mellitus whereas the two-step approach identifies lesser positives compared to the former. Overall, the adverse effect outcome for both tests is the same.

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What is the type of presentation depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The presentation depicted in the image is complete breech, where the lower extremities are flexed both at the hip joint and also at the knee joint.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Frank breech: Breech with flexion at hip joints, extension at knee joints.
  • Complete breech: Breech with flexion at both hip joints, one or both knees at flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extension at one or both hips, as a result, one or both feet or knees lie below the breech. Footling is a type of incomplete breech with one or both feet below the breech.

Footling breech:

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is :
questions.solution:
The hormone acting on the post ovulatory endometrium is progesterone.

In the post ovulatory period, there is an immediate rise in progesterone levels, secreted by the developing corpus luteum.This phase is called the luteal phase where the vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg. Oestrogen levels also increase, however the rise is seen only from the mid-luteal phase.

If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, oestrogen and progesterone levels decrease abruptly. This prompts the shedding of the  superficial layer (decidua functionalis) of the endometrium.

The normal menstrual cycle consists of the following phases :

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days)
  2. Follicular phase (10 -14 days)
  3. Ovulation (14th day)
  4. Luteal phase (14 - 28)

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for PCOD?

choices.text: At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
The ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.solution:
In polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD),at least 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm should be seen on an ultrasound.

 USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume >10 ml
  • These ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on combined oral pills, as these pills alter the ovarian morphology.
  • Single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European society of human reproduction and embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovarian syndrome:

National Institute of Health (NIH, 1990):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation

Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Necklace appearance of right ovary on USG in PCOD:

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 7 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

questions.text: A woman has a history of postpartum haemorrhage and lactational failure. She presents with complaints of amenorrhoea after one year. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Sheehan's syndrome. 

When postpartum haemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, it causes panhypopituitarism. This is known as Sheehan’s syndrome. Damage to the other specific pituitary cell types causes:  

  • failure of lactation
  • loss of sexual and axillary hair
  • hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency

Option B: Rotor syndrome is an autosomal, recessive disorder presenting with mild jaundice. On examination, it presents with mild hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Acromegaly is characterised by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: Your senior resident while screening for cervical cancer in a 36-year-old female, advises for a  pap smear test. She asks you regarding the prerequisites of this test. Which of the following is not required in this case?

choices.text: A vaginal examination is required before taking a pap smear
The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test

questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Pap smear should be done before performing a vaginal examination because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test

  • It is a screening test only.
  • A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.
  • It can be used for screening premalignant and malignant conditions and can also identify other local conditions.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • Ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test.

Procedure

  • The patient is put in dorsal position & labia parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slide.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear (from squamocolumnar junction, portion vaginalis of cervix)

Endocervical brush: to take endocervical sample.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of tumor specimen reveals sheets of mucin-producing signet ring cells as seen below.  Identify the true statement regarding this ovarian tumor.

choices.text: Normal shape of ovary is retained
Ovary is attached to nearby viscera and becomes immobile

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing signet ring cells is suggestive of Krukenberg tumor and in this ovarian tumor, the normal shape of the ovary is retained.

Krukenberg tumor: These are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from a primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral (Option D)
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis (Option C)
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule (Option A)
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, Numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female complains of bleeding per vaginum for 1 week. Her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. She does not complain of fever or vaginal discharge. Physical examination shows a small amount of dry blood along her vaginal wall. USG examination performed shows increased endometrial thickness.  Which of the following statements is false regarding fractional curettage for this patient?

choices.text: Endocervical curettage is done after cervical dilatation
Following dilatation, the isthmic portion is curetted
Uterine cavity is curetted finally and usually sent separately
It is indicated due to suspected endometrial carcinoma

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a post-menopausal bleed that is suspicious for malignancy. In fractional curettage, Endocervical curettage is done prior to cervical dilatation.

Fractional curettage:

  • It is indicated in suspected endometrial carcinoma.
  • In this procedure, endocervical curettage is done prior to cervical dilatation. Following dilatation, the isthmic portion is curetted and the tissue kept in a separate bottle.
  • Thereafter, the uterine cavity is curetted and sent separately.

Fractional curettage determines the extent of spread of malignancy down the uterine wall, so that staging can be done and appropriate treatment planned. Involvement of endocervical lining places the malignancy in stage II of the disease

Note : 

Procedure of Dilatation and curettage:

  • Dilatation and curettage is performed under either sedation, paracervical block or general anaesthesia. Local anaesthesia is adequate in a multiparous woman, but a nulliparous or an apprehensive woman may require general anaesthesia.
  • The woman is put in the lithotomy position.
  • Bimanual examination is done to ascertain the size of the uterus and its direction and to rule out adnexal mass.
  • With the help of Sim’s speculum and anterior vaginal wall retractor, the cervix is exposed and the anterior lip held with Vulsellum or Allis forceps.
  • The uterine sound confirms the size of the uterine cavity and its direction.
  • The cervix is dilated with a dilator and the curette is introduced into the uterine cavity and the uterine lining scraped from above downwards all round.
  • A gritty sensation indicates the end of curettage.
  • The tissue is preserved in 10% formalin. For culture and PCR, the tissue is sent in saline.

Normal endometrium appears pink and healthy. Profuse, pale-looking and friable tissue suggests malignancy. Fractional curettage determines the extent of spread of malignancy down the uterine wall so that staging can be done and appropriate treatment planned. Involvement of endocervical lining places the malignancy in stage II of the disease.

Note :

Endometrial biopsy is performed as an outpatient procedure without anaesthesia or under sedation. The cervix is not dilated and a biopsy curette is inserted and a strip or two of endometrial tissue is obtained for histological study.

Sims curette is shown above

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Sim's speculum is used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele.The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualisation of the vaginal walls.

Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining.

The Veda-scope is a recently developed alternative to bivalve speculums. The instrument creates an air tight seal at the vaginal introitus and the vagina is inflated with filtered air. Following inflation, the vaginal walls can be examined and tests such as VIA VILI (Visual inspection with acetic acid and lugol’s iodine) and pap smear can be performed. It also allows for taking pictures with a camera and introducing a light source.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. What is the best management?

choices.text: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks
Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks

questions.solution:
The definitive management of PIH/eclampsia is termination of pregnancy.

Indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, in cases of pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Fetal compromise

Option B: In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks

Option C: MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia in patients with severe pre-eclampsia and pregnancy is terminated at >34 weeks. If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks, corticosteroids are given and patient is delivered after 24 hours of the last dose of steroid.

Management of severe pre-eclampsia is outlined in the following flow chart:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, history and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Mild: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can be caused by the following:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) 
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

It causes secondary amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, habitual abortion and infertility depending upon the extent of uterine cavity obliteration.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography provides an excellent alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

questions.text: The CTG tracing of a woman in labor at 38 weeks gestation is shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like- post maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

Other options:

Option A: The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

Option B: The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

Option D: The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: A 24 year old primi with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG.  The USG done is suggestive of

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
The above USG is suggestive of Hydatidiform mole.

The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appear as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has less hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.


Classical clinical features of a complete mole are-

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation:

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.solution:
A history of cyclical abdominal pain, primary amenorrhea and a bulging vaginal membrane suggest cryptomenorrhoea caused by an imperforate hymen.

Cryptomenorrhoea:

  • Also known as hematocolpos, is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.
  • Most common cause is an intact (imperforate) hymen or the presence of a vaginal septum.
  • A vaginal septum is differentiated from the imperforate hymen by a pinkish concave covering in contrast to the bluish convex bulge in the latter.
  • An ultrasound scan of the pelvis confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:- A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function, in cases of imperforate hymen.

Note:

In the case of a vaginal septum (i.e atresia), more extensive dissection and vaginoplasty are required.

questions.text: A 25-year-old, G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to AMTSL. Which of the following is not recommended in active management of the third stage of labor according to WHO?

choices.text: Oxytocin given within 1 minute of delivery

questions.solution:
Uterine massage is not recommended according to WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate (within 1 minute) administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women
  • Uterine massage is not recommended

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL yet may be recommended by some and to be considered with the warning that evidence for this practice is not strong.

questions.text: Absence of uterus and vagina in a genotypic female with normal secondary sexual characteristics is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. A blind-ended vaginal pouch is present in 25% of patients.

Ovaries are normal and secondary sexual characters are well developed with normal external genitalia. This condition is associated with anomalies of the spine/skeleton and the kidneys along with the urinary tract.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old female with endometriosis, which of the following clinical findings do you least expect to encounter?

choices.text: Cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments on posterior fornix examination
Freely mobile painless Nodular mass on abdominal examination
Bluish puckered spots over posterior fornix on speculum examination
Lateral forniceal tenderness in vaginal examination

questions.solution:
Abdominal examination in endometriosis would typically reveal a fixed, tender, cystic swelling, not a freely mobile painless Nodular mass.

 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: All of the following are protective factors for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) except _________
questions.solution:
IUCD users are a risk factor for PID and not a protective factor.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

Note: Several studies in developed and developing countries have found that current or recent OC use reduces the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, a major cause of female infertility. These studies have found that OC use lowers the risk by, on average, about 40 percent. Two mechanisms may be operative:

  • OCs may change the cervical mucus such that it prevents pathogenic organisms from ascending into the upper genital tract; or
  • OCs reduce menstrual blood flow, thus decreasing the amount of medium available for bacterial growth.

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: Single dose of drug used in emergency contraception ______
questions.solution:
Single dose of drug used in emergency contraception is Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg.

Levonorgestrel (LNG):

Prostinar tablet contains 0.75 mg LNG. One tablet should be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later. Alternately, two tablets can be taken as a single dose. The failure rate is 1.1%. The tablets can be offered up to 120 h but its efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval. LNG prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency). The period may come earlier or delayed.

Side effects are those of progestogens. The hormone is not teratogenic in case pregnancy does occur but risk of ectopic pregnancy remains.

Advantages:

  • It has no oestrogen and its associated side effects
  • It can be offered to hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic woman
  • It can be offered to a lactating woman
  • It can be given as late as 120 h after the unprotected intercourse
  • Single-dose therapy is an advantage

Contraindicated in liver disease, contains lactate, so allergy to galactose. The drug is also contraindicated in a woman with history of thrombophlebitis and migraine.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills
Combined pills(COC)

MALA-D(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+Ferrous Fumarate) 

MALA-N(Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+EE 0.03 mg+ferrous fumarate) Govt supply. Free of cost. 
Progesterone only pills(POP)

Low dosage of progesterone, mainly norethisterone and levonorgestrel

Suitable for lactating women
Once a month(long-acting) pills

Long-acting oestrogen(quinestrol)+ short-acting progesterone

Highly disappointing results
Male pills(Gossypol)

Cottonseed derivative

Causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

Post-coital pills (Interceptive)

 		 Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg tablet within 72 hrs and same dose after 12 hrs OR 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hrs
RU 486(Mifepristone) doses ranging from 10-600mg.
Ulipristal(30 mg) within 5 days
Centchroman: 2 tabs(60 mg) within 24 hrs
 GnRH agonists
CuT IUCD: inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

Progesterone only injectables

 

DMPA: 150 mg IM every 3 months

NET-EN: 200 mg IM every 2 months 

Combined injectables

  

Cyclofem: 25 mg DMPA+5 mg estradiol cypionate

Mesigyna: 50 mg NET-EN+5 mg estradiol valerate 

 

Subdermal implants

35 mg levonorgestrel

Norplant II/Jadelle

Two rods with 70 mg levonorgestrel each and a release rate of 50 mcg/day

Others

Hormonal IUCD

Mirena: 52 mg of LNG with release rate of approx. 20 mcg/day

The patch (ORTHOEVRA)

Norelgestomin+Ethinyl estradiol: Weekly for 3 weeks then patch free 1 week

Vaginal ring (NUVARING)

Etonogestrel+ethinyl estradiol daily release. Use for 3 weeks with a withdrawal week.

questions.text: Which of the following recommendations will you give for a woman entering her 4th month of pregnancy,  regarding the supplements to be taken in according to the 'Anemia Mukt Bharat' scheme of the Government of India?

choices.text: Take one red tablet (45 mg elemental Iron + 400 μg Folic Acid) everyday from the 6th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
Take one red tablet (60mg elemental iron + 500 μg folic acid) everyday from the 4th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
Take one pink tablet (100mg elemental iron + 500 μg folic acid) everyday from the 6th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
Take one pink tablet (45 mg elemental Iron + 400 μg Folic Acid) everyday from the 4th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery

questions.solution:
The Anemia Mukt Bharat guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid daily at least for 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy and continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must also be followed for 180 days postpartum.

This patient, being illiterate, should also be made aware of the color of the tablet which is red. This would help ensure she takes the correct tablet and does not end up taking a pink IFA tablet which is given for Children 5-9 years of age and contains only 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg Folic Acid.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

A key intervention is to give IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of anemia, under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme.

Note: These values are specified for the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme (2018).

Age group Dose and regime

(6-59 months of age)

Bi-weekly

1 mL iron and folic acid syrup.

Each mL iron and folic acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid.

Bottle (50 mL) to have an "auto-dispenser" and information leaflet, as per MoHFW guidelines in the mono-carton
Children
(5-9 years of age)

Weekly,

1 Iron and folic acid tablet.

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated, pink-colour.

School-going adolescent girls and Boys
(10-19 years of age)

Out-of-school adolescent girls
(10-19 years of age)

Weekly,

1 iron and folic acid tablet.

60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated, blue-colour.

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating)
(20-49 years)

(Under Mission Parivar Vikas)

1 iron and folic acid tablet.

60 mg elemental Iron + 500 mcg Folic Acid, 

Sugar-coated and red-color.
Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers
(of 0-6 months child)

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days during pregnancy) and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red-color

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Ref: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/home/interventions/

questions.text: A primi at term presented with labor pain and multiple painful vesicular lesions on her vulva. No rashes were found on other parts of the body. What will be the management of this case?
questions.solution:
This case is managed with acyclovir and elective cesarean section. The presence of multiple painful vesicular lesions on the vulva indicates a diagnosis of active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. 

Women with genital herpes (both HSV 1 and 2) during pregnancy possess a risk of vertical transmission of the infection to the fetus. The risk of transmission is higher in primary HSV infection than recurrent. The maximum risk of fetal infection is during labor, although it can occur in utero and post-natally from direct contact. 

Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in:

  • Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent
  • Prodromal symptoms like vulval itching or burning

Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir should be given if found positive. Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions in non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery. 

Management of HSV infection during pregnancy:

  • Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir for primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy.
  • IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir for severe or disseminated infection
  • Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics for pain relief
  • Catheterization for urinary retention

Other options:

Option B: The presence of active genital lesions is a contraindication to the induction of labor.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of GSI :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walk, going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergics, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

(LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin)

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start LMWH.

Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, and fetal embryopathy if used in the first trimester. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin.

Period of gestation Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

 LMWH or UFH
13 to 36 weeks Warfarin
36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery LMWH or UFH
6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin, UFH- Unfractionated heparin 

It is recommended that all women on warfarin switch to LMWH or IV UFH at weeks 34–36. Since giving IV UFH untill delivery is difficult, LMWH would be the better option till UFH is started. UFH should be started approximately 24 hours prior to labor induction or caesarean. IV UFH should be stopped once in labour or 6 hours prior to caesarean. UFH should be restarted 4 to 6 hours post-vaginal delivery or 6–12 hours post-caesarean section. Warfarin should be restarted on day 1 postpartum (uncomplicated vaginal delivery) or on day 2-3 if caesarian or bleeding complications occur.

Heparin should be discontinued just before delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then iv protamine sulfate can be given.(Easy reversal of anticoagulation). Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed at 5 minutes after birth. He is found to have a heart rate of 110bpm, coughs on stimulation, and has a strong cry. His limbs are well flexed, the body is pink, but extremities appear blue. The Apgar score for this newborn is ______
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this newborn is 9.

In this baby:

  • Body pink, extremities blue: score 1
  • Heart rate, >100 beats/min: score 2
  • Coughs on stimulation, score 2
  • Well flexed of the extremities: score 2
  • Strong cry: score 2

Thus the total score is 9.

  • At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition.
  • An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation?

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask  ventilation.
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.solution:
If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation.

Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.

questions.text: Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
• Jaundice due to erythroblastosis fetalis mostly manifests within the first 24 hours of life.
  • Other causes of jaundice in the first 24 hours of life can be concealed hemorrhages, sepsis, congenital infections like syphilis, rubella or toxoplasmosis.
  • Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus).
  • Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.
  • Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.
  • The image below is of a schematic to approach to diagnosis of neonatal jaundice:

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor

NO edema Edema is prominent
Voracious appetite, no apathy Apathy and loss of appetite
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen
No Fatty liver, no subcutaneous fat Fatty liver, Subcutaneous fat preserved

questions.text: Milestones may be delayed in a 15 month old child if he is not able to________

choices.text: Walk upstairs with 1 foot at a time

questions.solution:
Milestones may be delayed in a 15month old child if he is not able to build a tower of 2 blocks. A normal child can build a tower of 2 blocks at 15 months.

Other options:

  • A child walks upstairs/downstairs with 1 foot at a time at 2 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly associated  cardiovascular defect with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between first and second toes

A score based on eight signs in the diagnosis of Down's syndrome in the newborn (Hall's criteria)

  • Abundant neck skin
  • Mouth corners turned downwards
  • General hypotonia
  • Flat face
  • Dysplastic ear
  • Epicanthic fold
  • The gap between first and second toes
  • Protruding tongue

The presence of the last 3 points is considered clinically proven Down syndrome. It is suggested that this score should be used routinely for the clinical evaluation of every newborn where the possibility of a diagnosis of Down syndrome has been raised.

 Note:

Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability.

  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemia, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).
  • The most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: Features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

questions.text: A 4-years-old child is brought a history of 4 episodes of loose watery stools for the past 1 day which does not contain blood. On examination, the child is irritable. but eyes, tongue, and mouth are moist with skin turgor normal. On offering water he drinks normally and does not appear thirsty.What will you advise the mother regarding the treatment of her child?

choices.text: Give 25-50 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 50-100 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 100-200 mL of ORS after each loose stool
Give 250-300 mL of ORS after each loose stool

questions.solution:
The child has loose stools and is irritable. His eyes, tongue, and mouth are moist, he does not appear thirsty and the skin pinch is normal. This indicates that there is no dehydration in the child. Since the age of the child is 4 years, the child should be given 100-200 mL of ORS after each loose stool.

Management of no dehydration in the child

After each loose stool, the child should be provided ORS according to the age 

Age amount of ORS to be given after each loose stool
<24 months 50-100mL
2-10 years 100-200 mL
>10 years As much as the child asks for

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child who underwent an appendicectomy is brought to the emergency with complaints of abdominal distension and vomiting. The mother also gives a history that the child passed stools that looked like currant jelly and the ultrasound finding is as shown in the image. What would be the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the USG showing the doughnut sign(target sign) are suggestive of postoperative intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seen postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura.

90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrent intussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows: enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, neurofibroma, intestinal duplication cysts, leiomyomas, hamartomas, anastomotic suture line, enterostomy tube, hemangioma, or malignant conditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.

Clinical features:

The characteristic clinical triad includes:

  • Pain
  • Palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium enema shows the characteristic coiled spring appearance.

The above image shows the coiled spring appearance

Treatment:

  • Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis.
  • Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a success rate of 80-95% in cases of ileocolic intussusception
  • Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis and multiple recurennces.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis: The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia: This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele

Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A child presents with generalised edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urine analysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

Glomerular diseases associated with heavy proteinuria clinically manifests as Nephrotic Syndrome.

The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome :

  1. Hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL)
  2. Edema
  3. Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol> 200 mg/dL)

along with proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio > 2 to warrant a diagnosis of Nephrotic Syndrome.

Causes of nephrotic syndrome :

Primary/Idiopathic - 

  • Minimal change disease (most common)
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
  • Membranous nephropathy
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Secondary to diseases such as :

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus,
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura,
  • Malignancies (lymphoma and leukemia)
  • Infections (hepatitis, HIV, and malaria)

Other options :

Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) nephritis
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome (Option C)
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is most likely to be seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is associated with hypokalemic hypochloremic alkalosis.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e. hypokalemia  hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Persistent vomiting secondary to gastric outlet obstruction results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.

The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS):

It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age. It is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. 

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right (not from right to left), followed by projectile vomiting.

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis is a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Management includes the correction of metabolic abnormality before the correction of the pylorus. The hypertrophic pylorus is surgically corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: A one-and-half-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min with chest retractions and no danger signs. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute respiratory illness. According to the recent WHO guidelines,  this child can be classified as having 'Pneumonia'. The treatment is oral amoxicillin and home care advice.

 Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate
    • Which distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not
    • > 50 for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40 for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Which indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Which indicates those with severe pneumonia who require hospital admission.

The following table gives the classification for cough / difficult breathing from 2 months to 5 years of age:

The recent WHO guidelines states that chest indrawing and fast breathing is in category of pneumonia.

Signs of severe pneumonia are :

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A male infant was brought to the emergency pediatric unit with abdominal distention. There was a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On examination, he was found to have urinary retention. Imaging showed bilateral hydronephrosis. What could be the probable diagnosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with USG finding of bilateral hydronephrosis is suggestive of posterior urethral valve.

Posterior urethral valve:

  • The valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum
  • They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. A urethral catheter can be passed retrogradely.
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder
  • If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infection in the neonatal period or with uraemia and renal failure
  • The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography
  • Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with continuing lifelong supportive treatment of the dilated urinary tract, the recurrent urinary infections and the uraemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • PUJ obstruction
  • Congenital small ureteric orifice
  • Inflammatory stricture following removal of ureteric calculus, repair of a damaged ureter, or tuberculous infection
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder cancer involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Calculus in the pelvis or ureter
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital:

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired:     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: The deformity shown in the following image below is characteristically seen in ___________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg), which is characteristically seen in rickets.

However, it may also be seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Clinical Features of Rickets:

General:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Listlessness
  • Protruding abdomen
  • Muscle weakness (especially proximal)
  • Fractures

Head:

  • Craniotabes
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed fontanel closure
  • Delayed dentition
  • Craniosynostosis

Chest:

  • Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison groove
  • Respiratory infections and atelectasis

Back:

  • Scoliosis, kyphosis, lordosis

Extremeties:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities
  • Windswept deformity
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia
  • Coxa vara

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis.
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification (becomes denser in healing rickets, known as the white line of Frenkel).

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta?
questions.solution:
Umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the placenta during the fetal period.

Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, with the exception of the pulmonary and umbilical arteries that carry deoxygenated blood.

Clinical significance:

1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery.

The umbilical artery has the following fate:

  • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
  • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments

2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Thus, identifying this during the head-t0-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.

Trisomy 18 is a common association.

The concept of fetal circulation and the various embryological remnants of the vascular entities of fetal circulation is a high-yield frequently tested topic in NEET-PG examination.  The concepts are summarized in the pearl attached below. 

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: The following test is done to assess
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pen test which is used to assess the median nerve.

It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is supplied by the median nerve. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is unable to touch the pen.

Median nerve lesions can be high lesions or low lesions depending on the site of injury.

Low lesions - It occurs due to injuries at the distal third of the forearm such as carpal dislocation or cut wound of the wrist.  There is paralysis of the hand muscles and the patient is unable to abduct the thumb. There is also a loss of sensation over the radial three and a half digits. The forearm muscles supplied by the median nerve are spared in these lesions. Wasting of thenar eminence is seen in long-standing cases.

High lesions - It occurs due to injuries above the elbow such as forearm fractures or elbow dislocation. There is paralysis of the forearm muscles along with all the features of low lesions.

Muscles supplied by the median nerve are given in the table:

In the arm No muscles
Proximal one-third of the forearm All the flexor muscles of the proximal forearm, except the flexor carpi ulnaris and the  medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus
Distal one-third of the forearm  No muscles
In the hand

Abductor pollicis brevis

Opponens pollicis

Flexor pollicis brevis

First two lumbricals

Other tests for median nerve: 

Pointing index sign or Oschner’s clasp test: The patient is asked to clasp both hands together. When this is done the index and the middle finger fail to flex due to the loss of action of long finger flexors which are supplied by the median nerve. 

Benediction test: Due to loss of activity of the long finger flexors the patient is unable to flex the index and middle finger on lifting the hand. As this is the position a clergyman uses to bless the couple during the marriage it is called the benediction test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the swelling and the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing an eccentric expansile lesion with a soap bubble appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor(GCT).

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment :

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting. 
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

Other options:

Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

 

Osteosarcoma:

It is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

 

Osteochondroma:

Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. The common sites of involvement are the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
