questions.text: With respect to tuberculosis of hip, which of the marked areas are affected commonly?
questions.solution:
The most common area affected is acetabulum which is marked as 1 in the figure.

Multiple cavitations occurs in femoral head and the acetabulum. Eventually, the head or the acetabulum gets partially absorbed. By the constant pull of the muscles acting on the hip, the remaining head of femur may dislocate from the acetabulum onto the ilium,giving rise to the so called wandering acetabulum.

Early stages of tb hip are characterised by synovial hypertrophy and effusion. The pannus of the hypertrophied synovium extends fully around the articular cartilage destroying it. The joint is filled with pus and granulation tissue.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

  • Stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb due to abduction deformity. 
  • Stage of early arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb due to adduction deformity.
  • Stage of advanced arthritis leads to true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  • Stage of arthritis with subluxation leads to true shortening of the limb. The destruction of acetabulum leads to dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

The sequential destruction is:

  • Dislocation of femoral head
  • Destruction of articular cartilage
  • Synovial hypertrophy
  • Multiple cavitations

questions.text: A patient who had applied plaster to his right leg for a tibial shaft fracture ,now presents with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent, on passive stretching the pain increases, and on opening the plaster, the leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Treatment: The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is utterly useless and the limb must be nursed flat, elevating the limb causes further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates the muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, Fasciotomy means opening all four compartments. Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement to be carried out.

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is _____.
questions.solution:
The given brace is Taylor brace.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Taylor brace is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support your spine whilst standing, sitting and walking after a spinal surgery.

Other options: 

Boston brace is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 

Milwaukee brace is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) introduced in the 1940s. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine. 

ASHE brace: anterior spinal hyperextension brace is used in dorso lumbar spinal injury.

questions.solution:
The characteristic sign in the given IVP depicts cobra head/ adder head deformity seen in bilateral ureterocele.

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An X ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray suggest intestinal obstruction with involvement of the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae connivente (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel). The gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae connivente give a string of beads appearance. 

Radiological features of bowel obstruction 

  • Small bowel - The involved dilated segments are straight and mostly centrally located. 
  • Jejunum - It is characterized by the presence of valvulae connivente with gas bubbles trapped between them. This gives a string of beads/ ladder effect. 
  • Ileum - The distal ileal obstruction is usually featureless. 
  • Caecum - A rounded gas shadow in the right iliac fossa is suggestive of caecal obstruction.
  • Large bowel - The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above is that of barium follow-through.

It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology. It is performed following a barium meal examination of the oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is inferior to enteroclysis where contrast is administered through NG tube. It is also used to evaluate the function of the small bowel.

Barium meal examines the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

Preparations and uses of Barium sulfate as a contrast in GI imaging:

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus).
  • Ba meal - 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum).
  • Ba meal follow through - 50% BaSO4 (for small bowel).
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel).
  • For Single contrast films, barium alone is used. Double-contrast films require air and barium which is better for a small mucosal lesion.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Perforation peritonitis and esophageal perforation: Iohexol is used.

The above radiograph shows barium meal. 

Barium enema: contrast is administered through a rectal tube and series of radiographs are obtained. It still remains the investigation of choice to visualize fine mucosal detail and also a very good technique for demonstration of general colonic configuration and caliber. The above radiograph is double-contrast barium enema with normal large bowel structure.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach.

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum.

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident and eFAST was performed on him. Which among the following statements is true regarding eFAST?

choices.text: It detects free fluid in the abdomen or pericardium
It helps in assessment of retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
eFAST/extended FAST helps in detecting free fluid in the abdomen and pericardium. 

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer to OT for surgery or for CT for further workup.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial (subxiphoid)
  • Right flank (hepatorenal view or "Morison's pouch")
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

eFAST/ Extended FAST assesses pleural (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluations), pericardial region, right flank, left flank and pelvic region. It is accurate in detecting > 100 ml of free blood. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury is difficult to diagnose. It is also unreliable in excluding injury in penetrating trauma. It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: The upturned cardiac apex in the boot-shaped heart which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot due to
questions.solution:
A 'boot-shaped' heart ("cœur en sabot" in French) is the description given to the appearance of the heart on plain film in some cases of Tetralogy of Fallot. It describes the appearances of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and a concave pulmonary arterial segment.

  • Other features are:
    • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
    • Normal size heart (Heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
    • 25% association with right-sided aortic arch
  • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has been classically characterised by the combination of the ventricular septal defect (VSD), right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO), overriding aorta, and a late right ventricular hypertrophy.

A 'boot-shaped' heart ("cœur en sabot" in French)

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D - Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of a heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

Note: Tremulousness is the first alcohol withdrawal symptom.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of a feeling of impending doom accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month is classified as panic disorder.

Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and PTSD.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific to social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 35 year old female complains of increased anxiety and repetitive thoughts of her hands being contaminated and engages in repeated washing of her hands. Her thoughts are distressing but she is not able to overcome them. If she tries to hold herself from washing, it further aggravates her anxiety. Treatment of choice is ____________
questions.solution:
Repetitive thoughts of contamination of hand and repeated washing is suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder(OCD). Treatment of choice in OCD is cognitive behaviour therapy.

The most common form of obsessive-compulsive disorder is contamination where they have repeated thoughts of their hands being contaminated and want to wash their hands repeatedly. The patients are aware of this, but if they try to resist, it leads to anxiety.

Note: Both SSRIs and psychological therapy(CBT) are first-line treatment modalities of OCD. However, the NICE guideline mentions that psychological therapy is more effective than pharmacological therapy and should be used as first-line where possible. 

Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders are:

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder
  • Hoarding Disorder
  • Hair-Pulling Disorder (Trichotillomania)
  • Excoriation (Skin-Picking) Disorder

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in munchausen syndrome?
questions.solution:
Antisocial personality is not seen in munchausen syndrome (factitious disorder). However, antisocial personality might simulate munchausen syndrome.

Antisocial personality disorder:

  • Similarities with munchausen syndrome: Pathological lying, lack of close relationships with others, hostile and manipulative manner, and associated substance abuse and criminal history.
  • Differences with munchausen syndrome: Antisocial persons, however, do not usually volunteer for invasive procedures or resort to repeated or long-term hospitalization.

Note: Antisocial personality is seen in malingering(pretend to be ill in order to escape duty or work).

Other options:

  • Munchausen syndrome features peregrination or frequent wide-ranging travel to seek medical care.
  • Patients with Munchausen syndrome often insist on surgery and claim adhesions from previous surgical procedures. They may acquire a gridiron or washboard-like abdomen from multiple procedures.
  • Patients with Munchausen syndrome (Factitious disorder) demonstrate pseudologia fantastica, a specific syndrome of autobiographical lying.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of correct endotracheal intubation?

choices.text: Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography
Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

questions.solution:
Breath sounds in the epigastrium is a sign of oesophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are:

Symmetrical chest rise, presence of equal bilateral breath sounds, absent breath sounds over the epigastrium, visible condensation in the ETT, large exhaled tidal volume, and appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation. But the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. It is the most reliable indicator of proper placement of the endotracheal tube (ETT) following intubation. It is indicated by a normal CO2 waveform for at least three breaths. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram represents the CO2 waveform displayed on the capnograph.

The given image shows the normal wave forms in a capnogram

 

Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2, though the surest confirmation for an advanced airway placement, does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.

Esophageal intubation: initial end-tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero. There would be the absence of breath sounds bilaterally with the presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Capnography in esophageal intubation:

 

Complete endotracheal tube blockage and circuit disconnection:

 

If the ETT is inserted too deep, it can lead to endobronchial intubation. If inserted too shallow, it can lead to accidental extubation. Thus, an adequate-sized tube should be placed with its tip midway between the vocal cords and the carina.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetics does not cause myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, a short-acting I.V. anesthetic agent doesn’t cause myocardial depression.

Etomidate is the most cardiac stable intravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Hence, etomidate is the I.V. agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and cerebral vascular disease.

Side effects of Etomidate:

  • The highest incidence of nausea and vomiting among inducing agents
  • Superficial thrombophlebitis and pain on injection
  • Adrenocortical suppression

Note: Although Ketamine has an indirect sympathetic stimulatory effect, it possesses a direct negative inotropic effect on the myocardium. Hence, ketamine has to be used cautiously in critically ill patients with shock, as they are prone to have a depletion of endogenous catecholamines. Ketamine infusion in such patients can unmask its direct negative inotropic effects and further decrease the blood pressure and cardiac output.

Hence, for this MCQ, Etomidate is the best answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the needle shown below and the procedure it is used for:

choices.text: It is used in obstetric anesthesia
It causes rapid onset of anesthesia within 1-2 minutes
It is used along with catheter for continuous infusions for pain management
The blunt tip needle prevents accidental dural puncture

questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It has a slower onset of action ranging from 10-20 minutes compared to spinal anesthesia which has relatively faster onset of action.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It finds its use in obstetric anesthesia, segmental blocks and chronic pain management.

Epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter.

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: During your neonatology rotation, you see the following apparatus being used to ventilate an apnoeic infant. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask. The part marked as A represents oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used to provide positive pressure ventilation. The bag is filled with oxygen and ambient air which are delivered to the patient when the bag is squeezed. It gets self-inflated when released.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to the hospital with the following complaints as shown in the image below. She noticed that these nail changes started appearing 2 months ago. There is no significant occupation history. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of nail psoriasis.

  • Nail pitting is the most frequent sign.
  • Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a highly specific sign seen in psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discolouration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.
  • Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time.
  • Nail pitting/ thimble pits are formed due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

A) Onychomycosis:

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many fungi may be causative.

Clinical features : A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

B) Arsenic poisoning:

Mee’s lines are seen in nails in arsenic poisoning. Mees lines (Transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands, in the arcuate form of the lunula. They reflect a systemic disorder like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. The pathology is in the nail matrix.

D) Lichen planus:

It is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes, often with a chronic course with relapses and periods of remission.

Nail involvement occurs in up to 10% of cases, majority cases present during the fifth or sixth decades. Fingernails are affected more frequently than toenails. The most common changes are exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

questions.text: Painless lesions over the vulval area as below is suggestive of ?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Condylomata acuminata.
It is also called as venereal warts. It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Human Papilloma Virus 6 or 11.
Verrucous, exophytic cauliflower like growths can be seen over the skin of vulval region, perineum, perianal region which are usually non tender.

Treatment -
local application of Podophyllin 25% in alcohol or Podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin for 6 hour daily,
Podofilox 0.5% solution
Trichloroacetic acid and bichloroacetic acid applied serially
Intralesional injection of Interferon

Vaccination - Cervarix at 0, 1 and 6 months; Gardasil at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Genital herpes - presents with painful blisters/ genital ulcer. It is caused by Herpes simplex virus 2.
Gonococcal vulvovaginitis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient usually presents with swollen, painful external genitalia and erythema around external urinary meatus along with foul smelling vaginal discharge.
Condyloma lata - these are infectious plaques which are broad, pink or gray-white present in warm, moist body areas. It is hallmark of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Acantholysis is seen in all except _____
questions.solution:
• Acantholysis is not seen in Bullous pemphigoid.
  • Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

Acantholysis may be either primary or secondary:

Primary Acantholysis

  • Primary acantholysis is due to the rupture of desmosome first, resulting in circular cells (acantholytic cell).
  • It is seen in conditions such as Pemphigus vulgaris, Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, Darier's disease, Hailey Hailey disease.

Secondary Acantholysis

  • Secondary acantholysis is due to the ballooning of the keratinocyte first, leading to the formation of circular acantholytic cell (also known as Tzank Cell).
  • It is seen in Herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2) and Varicella zoster infections (Chicken pox and Shingles).

Image: Acantholysis; note the rounded and free-floating, detached keratinocytes

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment used for the condition with the clinical finding given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows burrows that are found in Scabies. The first-line treatment for scabies is topical permethrin.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus.

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

It is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous). Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’.

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo
